div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: France and Germany.
div.p: If the statement that M. Delcasse is the real author of the now famous articles in the "Matin" is correct, the ex-Minister of Foreign Affairs has played his country a sorry trick in giving the world what common sense would have left unwritten and unsaid. Germany is still a dangerous power to provoke; the failure of her forces against the Hereos does not imply that they are unfitted for European warfare, their tactics, however unlike those of the Man- churian campaign, differing in no essential from those employed in the French manoeuvers, and the idea that a great anti-German conspiracy had been formed at the time of the first difficulties that arose from the Kaiser's visit to Morocco might enlist millions who have hitherto offered lukewarm support or frank opposition to the IMperial policy, in the cause of "Gott, Kaiser, and Vaterland." There is no question that the German military party, if unwilling to face France and Russia, would welcome the oppurtunity of encountering France single-handed, and the British offer of 100,000 men would not save the situation were the French armies to be overthrown on the frontier. We prefer to believe that M. Delcasse is too good a friend of his country and of the Anglo- French entente, to risk the future of both by so strange an in- discretion. To publish the British offers to aid France, to indicate the British plan of campaign, and to irritate German Chauvinists and French and British diplom- atists alike is not worthy of a diplomatist. The articles are more probable the work of some ingenious and sensational journalist anxious to see the "Matin" sell well, but even so they will not improve the continental situation, terribly strained by the efforts of Chauvinists, and complicated by the Austrian difficulty and the financial and military reverses of Russia. That an understanding between France and England is necessary, we admit; understandings are often the parents of alli- ances, but that the publication (or invention) of military and diplomatic correspondence of the highest importance exchanged between the two powers with a view to meeting an attack by the third, seems to us to be an extra ordinary error of judgement, calculated, unless promptly denied; to precipitate the event to avoid which the entente was sealed.

div.head: Lemco
div.p: "Energy Packed."
St. Petersburg, October 9.

It is reported tbnt thero will be 3OO,OOO Russian troops stationed on the Chinese frontier after the formal signature of peace, partly because the Government is apprehensive that these men might join the malcon tents at home, and partly with a view of intimidating the Chinese. (Reuter)

div.head: PROFESSOR BEHRING'S REMEDY.
MEDICAL OPINION.
div.p: Sir William Broadbent, the King's eminent physician, says that Professpr Behring's statement of the discovery of a cure for tuberculosis commands the respect and attention of the entire world, as emanating from the discoverer of the antidiphtheric serum and a man of high scientific reputation. His announcement of a curative agents only amounts as yet to conviction and awaits demonstration. It is hoped, however, that this newest tuberculin will not share the fate of its predecessors.
Paris, October 9.

It is the opinion of medical men that it will be a long time before Professor Behring’s remedy for phthisis will reach a practical stage, although the merits of his researches are undisputed. (Reutner)
Moscow, October 9.

The strike is spreading. There was rioting last night in which there were many killed and wounded including some Cossacks. The populace is exasperated by the brutality of the repressive measures. (Reuter)
Moscow, October 9.
A large military force occupies the main squares and streets here. (Reuter)
Moscow, October.9.
The strikes of the tramway workmen, compositors, and bakers continue. There is a great deal of disorder and the Cossacks have killed ten demonstrators. (Havas
Paris, October 9th

It is believed that the articles published by the "Matin" were inspired by M. Deleasse. They have caused a profound sensation in France and will tend to augment the animosity of France towards, Germany. The English newspapers are sceptical. (Reuter)
London, October 9.
Telegrams from Tiflis report, that several bombs were thrown on a detachment of Cossacks. The troops fired on the crowd and there are many killed and wounded. Panic is prevailing. (Reuter)
Buenos Ayres, October 9
Martial law has been proclaimed throughout tho Argentine Republic owing to the imminence of a general strike. (Renter)
Djeddah, Ootober 9.
The Turka in the Yemen have occupied Hajje unopposed. The next advance will be upon the Imam's stronghold of Sada. (R.)
Budapest, October 9
The appointment of a Ferjervary Ministry appears to be decided. (Havas)
Khahbin, October 9.
Indiscipline prevails in the Manchurian army. (Havas)
St. Petersburg, October 9.
The remains of General Kondratenko, the defender of Port Arthur, have arrived here. Several Grand Dukes and civil and military dignitaries were present at the imposing military funeral. (Reuter)
Stray ask Ownerless Dogs found in Old Cairo during to-morrow night and at dawn of the 12th will be poisoned by the police,
State Telegraphs.—A credit of L.E. 2,500 has been granted by the Ministry of Finance for the improvement of the telegraphic service.

Unsuccessful Examination. — We learn that the Board of Sheikh of Al-Alzhar University, Cairo, have examined forty students who were terminating their studies; two only have succeeded in passing and 38 failed! The fortunate two are Sheikh Mahmoud Ismail and Sheikh Mahrouss Sharaf.

The Bubonic Plague. — Only one case of bubonic plague was notified at Alexandria last week, there being no case in any other town in Egypt, and the number under treatment is now three. From the 1st of January to Saturday last 160 cases had in all been notified as against 812 during the corresponding period of last year.

Garrison Directory.- Our readers will be pleased to learn that it has been decided to issue a new edition of this useful publication about the end of next month. Any corrections desired or the insertion of the addresses of residents must be sent in before the 31st October to the clerk in charge, Garrison Directory, Headquarters office, Cairo.

Turkish Triumphs.—Marshal Faizi Pasba, commander in-chief of the Ottoman troops at Yemen, has despatched a telegram to his Government informing it that the Sultan’s troops had marched with triumph to Breem and occupied that town on the 22nd ultimo. The population are said to have been submitted without resistance, and to have prayed and beseeched Heaven to protect the Khalif and keep him victorious.

Prisoners by Deputy. — “Al Mokattsm" learns that two men of Meiet E! Ajeil, of Talkha markaz, Gbarbieh, who were recently imprisoned for some petty crime, proved to have replaced the real culprits. Both prisoners were identified as brothers of tho condemned men. These four brothers are said to he on bad terms with the omdeh of their village, and to be relatives of the ghaffir, who perhaps had a hand in arranging the interchange of the prisoners.

Bedouin Brigandage. — "A1 Mokattam” states that a band of Kadeirah Bedouin under their chief Azad el Kediri recently carried off fourteen camels belonging to a native named Odeh Melhoos close to El Arish. Their owner, terrified by the Bedoaiu, made no resistance, but informed the Governer af El Arish, begging that his camels should be recovered. Our contemporary adds that no measures have yet been taken tor the recovery of the animals.

Arment Teftish.—In our issue of tho 2nd instant we mentioned that the Government had, in response to a petition from the inhabitants of four villages comprised in the Ament teftish, decided upon returning the lands in question, which had hitherto formed part of the Daira Sanieh Administration, to the pet tioners on certain conditions. We are now informed that the price of sale has been fixed at £35 per feddan payable in 20 equal yearly instalments with interest at 5 1/2 per cent. per annum, and that the Agricultural Bank has keen entrusted with the collection of the annuities as they become due.

Orwat-el-Woska Schools— H.E. Risz Pasha recently paid a visit to the school which bears his name at Bacos, Ramleh, and expressed himself highly pleased with the excellent discipline maintained in tho school and with the progress and tidiness of the pupils. We learn that the Pasha not only publicly complemented the head master and the teachers on the results of their care and attention, but communicated with the President of the Orwat-e!-Woska Benevolent Society, announcing his intention of presenting each of them with a sum equal to a month's salary.

Sanitary Department. — The Direction General of the Sanitary Administration will remove next month to the large and commodious premises in the groups of of the Ministry of Public Works that are now approaching completion and cost some £4,500 to build. The present offices will in future be used for the auxiliary services and stores. Sir Horace Pinching and Professor Bitter, director of the Hygienic Institute, who have been representing the Egyptian Government at the Tuberculosis Congress in Paris, are returning by the French mail of next Tuesday. A director from the Pasteur Institute for the new Anti-Rubic Institute now being constructed by the Government, is shortly expected from Paris. This new Institute will replace the one which has until now been attached to the Italian Hospital at Abbassieb, and towards the maintenance of which the Government contributes a yearly sum.

div.head: THE PRINCES' CASE. FIRST AUDIENCE TO-MORROW.
div.p: The first audience in connection with the proces des Princes will come before the Judge de Refere at the Mixed Tribunal in Cairo tomorrow. The Daira Sanieh, Daira Sanieh Co., and the Credit Foncier together with the claiments—heirs of the late Khedive Ismail—have been summoned to appear and show cause why the sum of £2,000,000, the portion due to tho Government out of the payment which is to be made on the 16th instant to the holders of Daira Sanieh shares, should not be handed over to the Finance Ministry in spite of the attachment made by the Princes. Unless the attachment is removed by the judge, the monies will be paid in court and the Princes will be held responsible for the interest, viz : about £100,000 a year. The total amount that is to be paid to the shareholders and holders of founders' shares amounts to about the same sum that the Government claims.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive will visit the mosque of Sidi Bishr, Ramleh, for prayers on Friday morning. In the afternoon he will visit the Khedivial Yacht Club.

div.head: SUICIDE OF A BRITISH SOLDIER.
div.p: An inquest was opened yesterday at the British Consulate in Cairo before Mr. Pio Sciortino, Pro-Consul, to enquire into the circumstances attending the death of Private Charles Harris of E. Company of the Rifle Brigade, stationed at the Citadel, who shot himself in the head with his rifle while on sentry duty between the hours of 4 And 6 p.m. that day. The jury was composed of Messrs. D. Macdonald, A. Gregory,and A.G. K. Levick. After being sworn they proceeded to view the body at the Citadel, and on their return to court they heard the evidence of Private Alcoyne Bayliss, of the same company, who deposed how the deceased, on receiving a letter from England on Saturday and reading it, appeared depressed and more reticent than usual, and how he found the body near the tennis court with the rifle by the side and marks of blood on the ground, caused by the wound from the bullet, which entered the month and came out at the back of the neck. At this stage the enquiry was adjourned to this morning, for the purpose of hearing medical and other evidence.

div.head: DISMISSAL OF A VALI.
div.p: Our readers have doubtless remarked the numerous arrests and perquisitions effected by the Khafieh or Ottoman secret police in Syria at the expense of Egyptians or persons in frequent communication with Egypt during the spring and summer of the present year, to which we have given some prominences in our columns. It appears that the Turkish central authorities, alarmed by the temporary success of the revolt in the Yemen, and terrified by the reports of certain mischief-makers, who are unhappily domiciled in Egypt, of an impending Arab rising, have for some time past encouraged the local authorities to search houses for arms and seditions literature, to arrest sheikhs and notables, and in short to add fresh burdens to the lives of their subjects. It now appears that the Porte has begun to suspect the reports of its own agents, and an instructive story reaches us from Aleppo which goes far to support our view that the "Nahda Arabiya’’ bogy was used by unscrupulous agents to secure the Acquiescence of a frightened government in their corrupt and oppressive practices.

It appears that the Vali of Aleppo recently informed the Mabein that he had seditious news and begged to be allowed to convey it to Constantinople. Leave was granted him and the nervous governor informed the Porte that a terrible Arab plot to seize Aleppo was maturing and could only be checked by prompt and severe measures. He therefore begged to be allowed to seize all weapons and search every house in the town. The Government, which was aware that Aleppo contained large numbers of wealthy merchants, showed a certain reluctance to commence operations without getting further details of the plot. Enquiries proved that the story of the conspiracy was based on the flimsiest evidence ; the nervous Vali was removed and Nazim Pasha, ex-Vali of Diarbekir, rules in his stead.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman S.S. Sardinia arrived at Liverpool yesterday.
The Ellerman S.S. Avon sailed from Malta last night, and is due at Alexandria on Friday with general cargo.

The Russian Steam Navigation Co’s S.S. Tearitza wills sail on Thursday for Odessa, touching at Pitaeus, Smyrna, Dardanelles, and Constantinople and connecting with the same Company’s mail hosts for Sevastopol, the Anatolian, Crimean, and Sea of Azov ports.
The S.S. Creole Prince arrived at Manchester from Alexandria on Sunday.
The Canard liner Pavis, is due at Alexandria on Thursday, and will immediately begin loading cargo for Liverpool and America.
The new Moss liner Menepthah sailed from Liverpool on last Sunday,is due at Alexandria about the 22nd inst. with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The Moss liner Remeses arrived yesterday evening from Liverpool, vit Gibraltar and Malta with passengers, mails, and general cargo.

div.head: THE END OF THE BLOCK.
div.p: The first outward bound steamer to come out of the canal since the stoppage, was the M.M. mail steamer Yarra, which arrived at 7.35 p.m. yesterday, and was followed by 27 more steamers,the mail boats coming first. The distance between the steamers was a mile and the whole canal presented a rare sight owing to the numerous searchlights of the vessels.

With the exception of a collision of the Austrian Lloyd steamer Africa with the Dutch Mail boat in the canal, all went on remarkably well, and by 5.20 this morning all the steamers were in the Suez bay. A few steamers are still detained at Suez, as they have not yet received tje electric light projector necessary for the passage of the Canal.

div.head: THE NUBIA REFLOATED.
div.p: The Anchor Liner Nubia was successfully refloated yesterday afternoon at 1.30 with the assistance of the Khedivial liners Fayoum and Calionbieh, and the pump is keeping Control over the leakage. She is expected to teach Suez in a day or two under her own team, where she will undergo the necessary repairs.

div.head: PORT SAID HARBOUR.
div.p: Thirty four boats have now arrived from Suez, this mail boats coming first. The harbour is still very full of vessels and it has been found to necessary to order six or seven incoming boats to anchor outside until the second batch of those which are in harbour have entered the canal, which will probably be about half past six to-night.

Sir William Garstin is progressing as well as could be expected after his recent operation. He is still confined to his room and at the Ministry of Public Works it is not expected that be will return to Egypt for some time to come, Sir William having been ordered to the South of France as soon as he is able to travel.
H.R. Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha has arrived at Alexandria from Constantinople.

Among those who arrived yesterday by the Norddeutscher Lloyd S.S. Schleswig we noticed H. H. Prince Fouad Pasha, Sir Vincent Corbett, Marshal Ghazi Ahmed Pasha, Dr. and Mrs. Warnock, Mr. C. Baehler, Mme and Mile Tamvaco, M. Cesar Adda, M. and Mme Agathon Bey, Dr..and Mrs. Williams and others.
Mr. Alban, British Consul in Cairo, arrived this morning at Port Said from Marseilles by the Bibby liner Cheshire.
Kaimakam R.E. Sheehan Bey, director, Northern Directorate, Coast Guard Administration and Mrs. Sheehan have returned from Europe.

Lieut. A. Carton de Wiart, 4th Dragoon Guards, son of the well known Cairo advocate, has been appointed A.D.C. to General Sir H.J.T. Hildyard K.C.B, Commanding the forces in. South Africa. He will hold the local rank of Captain.
H.I.M. the Sultan has conferred the rank of Haramein upon Mohamed Bey Neahar, son of the late Abmed Pasha Neshat of Cairo.
Mr. R. J. Hughes of the stock department of the National Bank at Cairo, has been appointed to the credit and accounts office of tho State Railways.
M. Ansaldi, acting director of the French Post Office, has been appointed controller of the Maritime Postal Service at Bordeaux, and is leaving Alexandria to-day to take op his new duties.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB. SATURDAY’S AQUATIC SPORTS.
div.p: The third annual aquatic sports of the Alexandria Swimming Club were held in the new Graving Dock, Gabbari, on Saturday afternoon before a large gathering of visitors which far excelled the attendance on previous occasions, and showing how much the club is advancing. Among those present we noticed H.H. Prince Aziz Hassan, Rear-Admiral Sir R. Massie Blomfield, K.C.M.G., and Lady , Blomfield, Mr. Freeman, acting British Consul General, and Mrs. Freemau, Mr. Ambrose Ralli, Vice-President of the Municipality, Mr. Critchley, manager of the imperial Ottoman Bank, and Mrs. Critchley, Artin Bey Rizian, and many others of the elite of Alexandria. During the coarse of the afternoon a telegram was received from H.E. Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha, regretting his inability to attend, and expressing his wishes for an entirely successful afternoon, and Mr. A. Mitchell Innes, Under Secretary of State, Ministry of Finance, also wrote regretting that a previous engagement prevented him being present and wishing the club every success in their meeting. The weather was delightful, but the burning sun was rather trying during the earlier part of the afternoon. The want of a swimming bath is the more especially felt on these occasions, end we express the hope that at no very distant date the Municipality will make an effort to supply this long-felt want. There are a large number of swimmers and bathers in Alexandria, and during the hottest parts of the trying summer days the luxury of a bath is denied to the many who are unable to afford the time to go out to the covered baths at San Stefano or Mex. As we prophesied, some excellent swimming was witnessed, and so well were the handicaps framed that the spectators were more than once at a loss to distinguish between the winner and swimmer-np. The dock was very effectively decorated for the occasion with flags and, with the gay assembly, presented a very animated scene. Mounted and foot policemen, kindly provided by the authorities, kept the approaches and entrances clear; in fine everything had been most excellently arranged and the organising committee are to be congratulated upon the success with which their hard labour met. Mr. Walter F. j Sarjeant, chairman of the club, showed himself to be a hard worker and able adviser ; Mr. H. S. Martin, hon. sec., who has devoted every moment of his spare time to the work since his return from leave, must be especially pleased at the reward of success, which was in a very large measure due to him; and we most not omit to mention Messrs. Purvis and Webb, under whose supervision the dock had been prepared to receive the members of the club and their guests. Mr. D. Dampergola's Orchestra helped to enliven the proceedings with a number of selections admirably rendered. But to turn to the sports themselves: these, though not astounding when compared with the world’s records, were nevertheless of a high class and showed what great good the formation of n swimming club in Alexandria had done. The progress was marked and the performances of the juniors were especially creditable, and pleasing as promising a great future for the club. For event I., which consisted of the four preliminary heats of the 60 yards handicap for H. E. the Sirdar’s medal, seventeen competitors turned out. In the first heat A. A. Eeclestone and N. W. Ames cameijn 1st and 2nd respectively, in the second heat W. Wood and C.S. Scarth ; in the third E.A. Darton and G. N. Cheeseman, aand in the fourth P.E. Harrison and W. 0. Mace. Event II. was the 60 yards juniors' handicap for members under sixteen years of age. Five boys competed and the excellent handicapping was shown by the nearness of the race. Harry Ecclestone, a boy only just turned si. years, went off in nob’e style and the plucky little fellow kept his lead to the end amid loud shouts of "Go it, nipper." W. H. Talbot, however, drew up to the leader very well and was closely followed by C. E. L. Randall, who had to give 85 seconds start to Elsworth, and between the first three competitors there was barely the difference of a "touch." Event III., 60 yards veterans’ handicap for members of 35 years of age and over, was won fairly easily by W. Wood, but only a few inches separated A. Jackman and M. B. Irvin, who came in 2nd and 3rd respectively. The final of the Sirdar’s medal handicap was then swum off, the competitors being W. Wood, G. N. Chessman, P. E. Harrison, N. w. Ames, C. S. Scarth, E. A. Darton, W.O. Mace and A. A. Ecclestone. Ecclestone was scratch, conceding seventeen seconds to the limit man, and he won the race in a splendid manner. Starting off with a clean and strong stroke he almost immediately gained ground, and as the winning point was approached he just managed to overhaul Darton. His excellent swim and graceful action excited general admiration, and he was hailed as winner with loud applause. Darton, too, made a splendid fight, gaining second place, and Cheeseman came in a very good third. The juniors diving championship, for which a cup was presented by the hen. sec., followed. The diving which was from 3.5, and 8 feet, was not of an exceptionally high order, but considering the ages of the competitors it was as good as could be expected. Randall secured the cup and Mitchinson and Harry Ecclestone were awarded 2nd and 3rd places respectively. Event VI plunging championship, followed. As in previous years much difficulty was experienced, in marking off the distances but the judge finally placed Ames, A.B. Collier, end Mace. 1st, 2nd, and 3rd in order of the names. The prizes for this event were very kindly presented by the Alexandria Tramway Company Ltd., while the cup was given by the Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Co. Event VIL was a pole watch between the Alexandria Swimming Club and the Eastern Telegraph Company which was very evenly contested, though the E.T.C. had not been been able to practice for the match. The club were the first to score, Darton throwing in with splendid aim very soon after play began. ei d half time was called with the iowe care ab 1 to niL On changing ends the E.T.C. did better and drew even with a good shot from Incledon but only a minute before time. Ecclastone scored for the club and thus secured them the verdict. A ten minutes interval was then given but was not without some amusement; Mr. Martin, who bad been on dry land all this time, supervising and judging; was suddenly seized with a craving for the water and rushing along the spring board shoved off for a dive with the full force of his fourteen and a half stone; the board snapped and it was only the last fibers of wood which prevented it from accompanying him in his dive; he also gave some neat exhibition dives. The blindfold race insugurated the second half of the programme and afforded endless amusement. Some swam in circles, others returned to the starting point almost immediately, and not a few endeavoured to entangle themselves in tubs bad life-buoys which were placed on one side to await the obstacle race. Collier, swimming remerkably straight, won fairly easily and was followed by Mace and Lovell almost together. The seniors’ diving competition followed this and some very good diving was witnessed. The winners were, in order, Collier Ecclestone and Darton. The first, two tying for first place, had to dive again, when Collier gained the verdict owing to Ecclestone turning over slightly. Darton was inclined to "buck” but just kept outside the limits of the definition and his neatness obtained him third place. The obstacle race was most amusing and exciting. The competitors had to pass through life-buoys and barrels and over and under poles and some curious struggles were witnessed. Irvin the limit man looked a certain winner but on his return he stuck in a barrel and, being of no slight build, it was with great difficulty that he managed to extricate himself. The 1st, 2nd, and 3rd places were awarded to Ecclestone, Mace, and Scarth respectively. The Military polo match between teams of the Departmental Corps and Royal Berks was well fought but the former were distinctly superior and won fairly easily by 4 goals to 1. The Royal Berks were rather weakened by the department of their best men for Khartoum but they made a splendid fight against a strong team and there was very little fouling. Each member of the winning team received a money prize. The juniors then “walked the pole" and for this event, Randall secured the only prize. The seniors followed and Collier was the only competitor to take the flag out of its socket and therefore gained the verdict. When the military tug of war came off it was getting dark. The Departmental Corps and Royal Berks pulled against each other and as in the polo match the former won by two pulls to nil, and this was the concluding event.

Lady Btomfield then distributed the prizes supported by Prince Azic Hassan, Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, K.C M.G., Mr Waiter F. Sarjeant, and Mr. Martin, but be before we refer to this part of the programme we must mention that she was presented on her arrival at 4 p.m. with a beautiful bouquet by Mr. Walter F. Sarjeant, and at the conclusion she was asked to accept a very handsome silver card case from the club as a souvenir of the pccassion. After each successful competitor had reveived his reward Mr. Sarjeant made a short speech in which he thanked Lady Blomfield for her kindness and the interest which she took in the club as was shown by her presence there that afternoon at the centre of such a large gathering. H.H. Prinoe Aziz Haasan and Admiral Blomfield were, he said, very welcome guests. To Prince Aziz he had to offer the heartiest thanks on behalf of the club for the generosity whcch he had shown that afternoon in offering a prize for any race next year which the club might choose. It has since been decided that a 220 yards scratch race will be swum for the Prince's prize, which will be a valuable silver cup. Remarking upon the success of the club Mr. Sarjeant mentioned that when it was formed three years ago there was but a handful of members while now they numbered two hundred and seventy. Before the gathering broke up, Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield in a short speech proposed a vote of thanks to Mr. Sarjeant and the energetic committee who had organised the sports and expressed the great pleasure which it bad been to Lady Blomfield and himself to witness the excellent exhibition of the art of swimming which had taken place that afternoon. We must not omit to mention that the chairman of the Club has kindly given a silver cup for the seniors’ diving championship and that the captains of the merchant marine service trading to Alexandria have most generally promised to present a cup for a junior championship to be decided upon later.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB. REGATTA.
div.p: The handicap for to-morrow’s race is the me as last week.
Class I. Course E.
Class II. Course R.
N.B. In Course R the Boghas Pass mark must be left on the starbord hand, not Port hand, as printed on the Charts
As on Friday next the 13th inst. H.H. the Khedive has promised to visit the club,a special regatta will be held in his honor when his challenge cup will raced for Class II. only.
To-morrow at 4.30 and 5 p.m. respectively two preliminary heats will be rowed between the following clubs:-
1 Club Nautique Francais versus Club international Canotier.
2 Alexandria Rowing CLub versus German Sport Verein.

If any of the sailing boats find themselves near the course of the rowing boats they are requested to keep out of their way, although the courses have been specially chosen to avoid collisions at breakwater elbow buoy, where the rowing boats start.

div.head: THE SITUATION IN CRETE.
div.p: During the past three months affairs have gone from bad to worse in Crete. The situation, which was serious enough in the spring, has become infinitely more acute and more menac- ing, the prospect of a pacification has become more remote, the attempt, made by the foreign Consuls to arrive at an understanding with the insurgents has remltedln.failure, and to all appean^oe tho four protecting Powers are now confronted with tho painful necessity of crushing tho in-.urreotionary movement 'by force. The only alternative—that of yielding to tho demands of the insurgents and practic ally transferring the government of the island to Greeco—i* apparently not to be thought of, and the somewhat scandalous oantliot between liberators and liberated has already entered upon its earlier stagtoTWith the approach of winter it is probable that las. may be heart of the Cretan trouble; when the snow appears on c the mountains a portion of the insurgent forces will doubtless disperse, and temporary tran- qnillity may furnish a theme for soothing official assurances; but it is almost certain that tho earlier months of the spring will witness a recrudescence of the movement, and the prob- lem to be faced may dvou grow in difficulty, It is unnecessary to enter minutely into the question of responsibility for the present lamentable situation. From the accounts of the inception and progress of the revolutionary movement already published in the "Times” it will be gathered that the main , factors of trouble have been, on the one hadd, the growth of a bitter spirit of faction in Crete, and on the other the inability or unwillingness of the Powers to discern the stormcloud which for tho last four years has been gathering in the island. To (he deadly fend between the Cretan parties mnst, ini the first place, be ascribed the ill-euccow which has attended the recent efforts at pae tication, for the insurgents have been unwilling to' accede to any settlement which • would leave the High Commissioner and his friends at the head- of affairs; while the loyalists, or Court party, have been equally determined to thwart any arrangement which might enable their opponents to boast that they had obtained important constitutional or finan- cial reforms from tho Powers. Events of great interest and importance in other parts of the world have divorted the attention of official and unofficial Burope from the Near Bast in general end from Crete in particular, with the result that ' a situation has been allowed to grow op, both bore and in Macedonia, which sooner or later must add considerably to the Eastern 'problem. The questions involved in that problem lose none of their intrinsic impor- tance tecaose epoch-making events are taking place elsewhere, and. tho trite precept obsta principiis is none the less to be observed because the symptoms of ooming trouble are / comparatively insignificant. The matter of mischief, says the proverb, is no bigger than a midge’s wing. In the more recent developments of the the Cretan trouble, as in its earlier phases, the obstacles which confront the eflorta of the Powers towards pacification are mainly due to tho internecine character of the conthot between tbeiwo Cretan parties. Bach is determined to 'outwit-and, if porsiblo, to annihilate the other, and it would be an error to suppose that the difficulties in the. way of an arrangement emanate from the insurgent camp alqnt At the timo ol the outbreak the official1 party, for -obvious reasons, was unwilling to admit that "ibo men of Therisso” ootlld succeed in alter- ing tho political- status and persistently minimised the importance of tho rebellion to the Consols, who naturally waited /or develop- ments-in the hope that' it wonld die a natural death, as they were assured it must do, owing to want of support from the population in in general. But tho action of the Assembly in issuing a rival proclamation of unjfou with Greece, though intended to take the wind from the sails of tho insurgents, in reality in- creasod-their prestige throughout the island, while it diminished that of the official patriots, who, though willing to flout the Buropean Areo- pagus on papor. were not prepared to abide their oomfortable appointments;and allowed the Hellenic standard to be lowered by the foreigners without firing a shot At the same time a speech delivered by anch an inflaeitrial and high-principled patriot as M. Sphakiiiski, decided many wavorers to throw - in their lot with the insurgents. The categorical rejeotion-of the Union by the Powers (May La), ooup'od with a promise ot administrative and financial reforms and a threat of military and naval measures in case of contumacy, produced a sobering effeot on both parties, and it seems probable that if the Powers bad been ready at this moment to make a strong display of force and at the same time to unfold a definite and wide reaching project of reforms, the oonrse of events would have followed a different direotion. Bnt in- decision and a want of unanimity seemed to prevail among the various Cibiaets, whioh, to say the truth, were occupied with other matters: reiof iioemoit* arrived slowly,, and time, passed od, while the insurgent* were enabled to strengthen their position from one end of the island to the other. Above all, the fatal mistake was committed of allowing small bodies of the native gendar- merit, whioh the Opposition regards as the immediate instrument ofi a tyrannical Govern ment, to oome into armed ooi fliot with the insurgents, and, what was still more nnfertun ate, mixed detachments of gendarmerie anc international troops were sent into tip interior. This ill-advised policy was in oonsqQanoe with the'designs of the official party, whioh aimed at setting the Powers aux prises, with the insurgents ; it was ad’vooated by the French authorities, probably from ignorance of local conditions, and by the Basriam 600 motives ttot known to tbomielm The consequences has been that the international troops, whom the insurgents solemnly declared they regard- ed as friords and wonld never oppose, have been entangled in s series of engagements resalting in onto senary blrodshrd, and a spirit of hostility has been created on all sides which rendors an arrargoment more difficult in the futare. On Jone 4 the insurgents replied to the pro- clamatiori of tho Power*. They declared that they bowed to the decision of the four Govern- ments, bnt hoped^ftat until the protecting Powors shonld/fimi it possible .to grant the union with Grcooo they would permit tho in- troduotion of conditions of ljfo more in con- .formitv w\th the requirements of Civilii ition. They arow attention to the financial situation, pointing out that the island was opable to sop- port the expense of a separate Administration, and that while Crete, as a portion of the Turkish Empire, was not allowed to increase her injport tariffs, her exports, whether to Greece or Turkey were treated as foreign mer- chandisn. They urged that the constitutional and autonomous govrirment intended by the Powors had boo a- converted into an absolute rfgime, that oonstifntional reform would prove a failure, snasmuch as there would be no goarantee for its conscientious application, and tjiattho substitution of a foreigner for the present High Commissioner would be hurtful to the Rational sentimonts of tho Cretans. They therefore begged that tho Powers,.while main- taining the nominal sureraioly of the Sultan, wonld entrust the government of the island to Greece, allowing the Cretans to make their own anangementsMn regard to the details of administration the two countries to form a single administrative -end financial organisa- tion.'‘With regard to the demand for disarma- ment, the doenmont pointed ont that, as the authority if the Cretan Government had disappeared in the,interior, an'axmed force was necossary for the maintenance ot publio ordot and for tho protection of the revolutionary Government against the attaoks of its enemies; that tho reappearance of the gendarmerie in the oountry districts wonld exasperate the population, bpt declared that, with the excep- tion of the neoeesary armed guards,, all the population wonld be summoned to) lay down arms. The solution propounded by the insurgents was not devoid in ingenuity as a means of pre- serving the international eituatioh while prao- tically bringing about the Union It resembled the projeot which has long found favor at Athens—the occupation of the.idapd by Greece on tho same line*'.at ih it of. Bos and Herze- govina by Austin, w.th the'moortant differ ence that the Cretans were to be left free to mike their own -bargain with the Hellooio I Government. The refu.-jU of the summons for j complete disarmament derived some justifies- tion from the fact that the Powers had taken no measures for the occupation of the interior, while tho partisans of the Government were already organising bands for the destruction of tho revolutionaries. 8o‘me little time before the reoeipt of tho insurgents’ reply two of the High ( Commissioner's counsellors had sent in their , resignation, and wbpn qooriicDed by tho ( Consuls with regard to their motives for this ' step avowed thoir intention of repairing to tho , mountains—not to join caato with tho men of I Therisso, bat to wage war against them. Fortn- , nately, wiser connsels prevailed, and the two , State officials have' not yet exchanged the pen for the rifle. After a decent interval, during which the Gpvernments of the protecting Powers were made aware of the obduracy of thS insurgents, another pfoclamati n was issued by the Consuls (Jnly 15) which partook of the character of an , ultimatum. A period of 15 days was aooorded to the revolntionarie8 for disafmament; those who obeyed were granted an amnesty; in case ( of oontumaoy the Powers reserved tha right of proclaiming martial law. This manifesto was read to a delegation of the insurgents by Mr. Howard, tho British Consul-General, as doyen -of the Consular Corps, who subsequently delivered a short speech in whioh he once more repeated the resolve of the Powers to make no change in the political status of the island at the present juncture, assured the in- surgents of the avertiop of the Powers to b.uodihed, but warned them of the fatal conse- qnonces resistance wonld entail both to them- refves and to tho welfare of their country, nich had already suffered great material losses owing to the prolongation of anarchy and dis- order. On the other hand, should they sub- mit,tbey wonld be guaranteed complete security of life and pr party, and the Consols would urge their Governments to oonvoke a National Assembly for. the purpose of^liciting Cretan opinion on the snbjeot ot reforms. In oonola- sion Mr. Howard stated that Prinoe George, who was much diftresaed by the c»lami*qne situation, wonld 4° his utmost to ensure the strict ’application of the prorpectivp reforms. The reply of the insurgent leaders to the ultimatum was flelirered to the Consuls on Joly 98 before the rnpiry of ths period laid down for dliarmsment Its tone vu rospoot- ful, bnt a hint was nevertheless oonveyed that the Powers wore too late In their proposals of reform, and that their a/quaintanoe with the existing conditions of tho Cretan problem sjas imperfect It was urged that the moral founda- tions of the present "provisional" rfgxrw had been destroyed by the Government, that the material means of maintaining it werelaokii'g. and that the insurgents would be guilty of a crime against their oonntry if they aooepted an inadequate solution which wonld only lead to fresh catastrophes. They W6re conscious of their weakness in face of the Powers, bnt were convinced of Ibe justioe of their caore and of the sinoerity with whioh the Powers pursued their programme of liberty and civilisation in be Crete, and expressed the belief that an in- oh veetigation eondneted on the spot wonld lead •1 the Powers to Acquiesce in their view, as ‘ It was dear from the general tenor of the oj fniorgente’ reply that their rwolntion bad ^een hardened by the nltimatiim, while they still dung to the hope that the Power* would reconsider thoir policy. The eta of military measures was now inaugurated, and oh July 30 the pons ala issued a proclamation announc- ing the establishment of martial law and in- vesting tho international authorities with special jurisdiction and other powers. Publio meetings were prohibited, and-the hearing of arms, except with permission of the international authorities, forbidden. The last-men- tioned regulation should be enforced with the utmost stringency in view of the growing dinger of civil war..' The arming of ejvilian partisans of the Government is a serious feature in tho situation, and one, of the lssf aota of the Chamber before its prorogation was to givo 1 ffid*l countenance and sanction to these ■ fc-callod guardians of the peace.* Their osstensible dnty-is to protect life^and property bat their real mission is apparently topnriue and exterminate the insurgents, the action of the international.authorities proving too len- iont for tho satisfaction'of party animosity- Tho engagement between the "anti-rovolu- tioniata” under one Uonalris and the insni- gents in the Eissamo district last week is indicative of what may bp expected to happen in every part ol the island should the armed partisans of.the existing rfgime be allowed to supplement tho regulir forces of the Powers- The Cretan Government, it is true, has die- claimed responsibility for the proceeding of Lionakis aud his fellows, some of whom, it hailod from Athens, bat the Buropean Powkrs, who object to the employment of irre- gulars with the Turkish foroee, should be the first to denoanoe and suppress these over realons auxiliaries omtheir own sidfcy With regard to the onforoembnt foTtbe mili- t*ry programme, a oartain differeqoe of apprp- oi ition seams to exist among the.With^ritios oftho various Powers. The lemons MWB by the Prenoh and Italian offioea fa Ckjea to- wards tho insnrgents has >roddcPd irritation in somo quarters, wbsre tija'foreigners are aoonscil, without any shadow of reaaop, of morally aiding the revolution. On the other hand, tho harshnoss and rigour displayed by tho Russians in the Retimo district are such as to recall the familiar methods of repression adopted in their own country. .The levying of heavy contributions from the villages, the horning of the insurgents’ houses, the regular employment of Christian Bashi-Botouks drawn for the ranks of their enemies, and the chases ii I'homme in the mountains, are, no donbt, effective proceedings in their way, bnt are hardly consonant with the civilising mission which tho Powers have undertaken in the is- land. Tho British authorities at Candia have also adopted severe measures, for whioh justi fication may be found in the neoessity for pro- tecting the large Mohamedan population of tho towo and district, which has been expo ed to aots of violenoe and outrage with the in- crease of anarchy. Those, however, who are familiar with the history of past revolutions in Crete will be slow to attribute all the evil doing to any party alone It is oonoeivable that the close of the open season and the approach of winter, with its hardships and privations, may engender a more pacifio spirit among the Cre- tan part-os, and that the work of reconciliation may bo resumed. Bat tho hope is a slender one aud tho ontlook for the present is gloomy 11 tho extreme.

div.head: SOLAR RESEARCH.
div.p: The concluding meeting of/the oonferenoe of the International Union for Cooperation in Solar Research was held in New College, Oxford, on the 29th nit. The proceedings wore mainly Of a formal character. With regard to tho plaoe and date .of tho next meeting, it was resolved to accept the invitation of M. Jan»»en to Mendon in/ September, 1907. Professors Schuster (oheirman) and Hale were oleated members of the ejecutiye oommittee, and.it \ras decidod that the central bureau ahoaid bo at tho University of Manchester, and, that tho computing bureau should he at tie Vni-' varsity Observatory, Oxford, qnder the direc- tion of Professor Turner. Committees were then elected to deal -with the following four subjects :—(1) standards of wave-length ; (9) solar radiation ; (8) oo-operation in work .with the speotro-heliograph ; (4) co-opera*i'n. in work on the spectri of sun-spots. On the motion of M. Perot, ihe'thanks of the con- ference were accorded to the Wardon and Fellows of Now College for their hospitality, and thanks were also voted to the secretaries, to Professor H:H. Turner, and to the Univer- sity of Manchester/for assistance in printing. The business meetings were adjourned till September, 1SK)7. After lunch in New College Hall the dele- gates travelled to London, and' io the evening attended a reoeption at the residence of the president of the Royal Astronomical Society and Mrs. Maw. The delegate* are invited by 8ir R. 8. Ball and Mr. H P. Newall to visit the observatory at Cambridge to^ty, and in the afternoon at 4.8O Professor Q. R Hale, of the 8olar Obser- vatory. Iff1- Wilson, California, has consented j to give a leoture in the Cavendish Laboratory, , by permission of Professor Thomson, on'“Tb# . Development of a New Method in Solar Re- learch-'’ Sir Norman Lookysr; has also invited the delegates; to visit the 8oleb Physlee Obser- 1 vstory, South Kensington.

div.head: END OF THE CYPRUS SEASON.
div.p: Nicosia, October 3.

The summer season is now drawing to an end, and althongh in the plains the days are hot and dose, the nights are beoomiog chilly and the general ippearanoe is that of early autumn. Throughout last mouth the xainfall I was nil for/*ho whv island, Now, in anticipa- tion of early rains, the farmers are preparing to onltivate their fields and "dry sowing” of r ooreals will very shortly commence.

The camps on Troodos are one by ore being 1 struck, and most of the visitors from E*ypt c have already loft that pleasant resort and have either returned to Egypt, or are spending a . week or two in Nioosia, and from there are visiting various places of interest prior to their departure.

Nicosia is a convenient centre for those who are able to remain only a short time b the Island, and who yet wish to see what there is 0(special btorest A pleasant day’s exoorsion may be made from there to Eyrenia, a distance of 16 English miles, and its lovely environs. This little seaport town on the north of the Island, with its gTand old fort and remains of 1 medieval glory, nestles snngly down by the 1 bine waters of the Mediterranean, into whioh it ] projects its miniature harbour. It has often : been described, and, snrronnded as it is by ' carob and olive groves, and backed by the long , serrated range of mountains which separates it ( on the south from the plains and which “like giants stand to sentinel th'enchanted land,” it has for generations been the object of enthn- siastio admiration on the parts of travellers. By making an early start by carriage from Nicosia, it is possible also to inolnde b the day's 1 programme a visit to'the pioturesque 14th | coatary Abbey of Belfapais, described in the "Handbook of Cyprus” as the "most beantifnl and important Gothio monument in the Le- vant" A more lovely situation than that selected for this glorions building can scaroely be fonnd anywhere. Rider Haggard, in his "Winter’s Pilgrimage to 8yria, Palestine, and the East" describes the view from the refeotory . window as unrivalled.

The grim fortress town and css tie of St Hilarion of unknown age, and whioh is perched | upon one of the topmost pinnacles of theKyrenia | range, provides another day excursion either I from Eyrenia or Nicosia. In the latter oate the carriage road is left about If miles outo(l Nioosia and mules are taken, which bring the traveller to the castle after aboht an honk's ride ; by taking lurch with ouo a delightful and not too' tifbg day may thus be spent. V Bnfiavento, another ancient mountain for- tress, cjnoerniog wjiioh “there are legends but no history”, should also be vi»\ted from Nioosia. It is.somewhat difficult of aooeas, but the carriage road brings one within three miles of the hospitable Monastery of 8tChrysostomo, and after a bait there for lanch, which visitors -should bring wjth them, an hour’s walk takes one to the summit and into the ruined castle. The magnificent view well repays one for the d fficulty of the journey. To the sooth it em- braces t early the whole Island of Cyprus, while on the north may be seen,Kyrenia and the whole length ol the Eyrenia mountain range, and across the Mediterranean the far distant boig'hts of the snow oapped Oaramanian mountains in Asia Minor. It .is much to be regr thst no handy pcoket guide briefly desoriptive of these plaoea of interest ii'obtainable; tourists consequently fail to sp- predate them ss fully as th# otherwise might. Now that the railway to Famagusta is completed; that onique old' town, rich in historical and architectural monuments, may also ba visited from Nioosia in a day.
